cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

wear out, scratch, etc.

in Cairo and Alexandria.

R.M.S. "Ormua" will leave Port Said Oct. 8
R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Port Said Oct. 21

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season (15th May - 15th September).

p.hi: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS

div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS(Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE,
In connection with Oriental Railway Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.

p.hi: PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.

div.p:
The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alter-
natley on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus),
Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout
in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.

p.hi: SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.----

div.p:
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Koosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednes-
days at 5 p.m. for port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express
services to Khartoum

p.hi: RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.----

div.p:
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for sinai
Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, hodeidah and Aden.

For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez or to Thos. Cook
& Son(Egypt) Ltd. Hamburg-Amerika Reise-bureau or other tourist Agencies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p:
Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular service fortnightly from Hamburg ;
weekly from Antwerp ; every 4 from Bordeaux direct to Alexandria ;
homewards every 2 weeks from Alexandria for Rotterdam and Hamburg.
Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway stations on direct
Bills of Lading to Alexandria, Cairo, Syria, etc. Special facilities for con-
veyance of cotton, etc. from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German
manufacturing towns.

EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA:
September 21st S.S. "Andros" from Hamburg and will leave on the 5th October for Rotterdam and Hamburg.
October 5th S.S. "Delos" from Antwerp.
October 9th S.S. "Chios" from Hamburg.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent. 15-9-907

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds
and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal
towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and
abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities,
current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p:
First-class Hotel, Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Renovated Throughout
Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Consulates and Opera House. Electric Lift. Perfect Sanitary
Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.

div.p: BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P,&O, S,N. Co.

Residents in Egypt proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested
to apply to our offices for information respecting their passages, where streamer plans
may be consulted, and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all pasrts of the
Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage
and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the
principle cities of Europe.

Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and
Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Company leave Cairo
thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady Halfa in
connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE. Steamers leave Cairo every Friday for Assouan and Halfa.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd
div.p:
Weekly Mail Steamers from Alexandria to Brindisi Trieste (Venice). Leaving
Saturdays at 4 p.m. having connection in Brindisi with the Express train on Tuesday
morning to Milan, Luoerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London. Arrival at Trieste on
Wednesday about 11 a.m. A train de Luxe leave the same evening, 6:35 p.m. for Vienna,
Fronkfort Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5:12p.m.

Weekly Intermediate Steamers from Alexandria to Trieste via Brindisi leave Alexandria every
Wednesday at 4.pm.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p:
One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia
Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its
own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons.
Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest
class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments
at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

sea bathing during the summer months.

div.p:
There is no change in the weather conditions. This
morning opens nice and clear with a light N:E
breeze and a steady barometer.

div.head: BIRTHS.
div.p:
ADAMSON.—On Friday, 13th September, 1907, at
Sunnyside House, Princes Park, Liverpool, the
wife of A. Adamson, of a daughter.

MAYNE.—On the 14th September, at Ellington
House, Maidenhead, the wife of Horace Mayne, of
the Egyptian State Telegraphs, of a daughter.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette

An English Daily Newspaper,
Established 1880.
div.p: Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Monday, September 23, 1907.

div.head: AN ANCIENT RELIGION.
div.p:
To the excellent little series, "Religions :
Ancient and Modern," which Messrs. Archi-
bald Constable are publishing, a new volume
is now added,dealing with the ancient religion
of Japan, and coming from the pen of the
author of "A history of Japanese Literature,"
Mr. W.G. Ashton. The volume is very small
and Shintoism briefly described, while the prac-
tical value of the work is considerably increased
by the addition of a short bibliography of books
dealing witht this subject.

Shitoism, in recent years, has llost som-
thing of its hold upon the Japanese, and Budd-
hism now attracts a large number of devotees,
while Christianity has an important following. The period when Shintoism flourished in an
unadulterated form is exceedingly remote, and
dates probably to the twelth century, if indeed,
that epoch had not already begun to register a
significant departure from the original standards
of the religion. Nevertheless, although Shinto-
ism contains evidences of a Korean element
as well as certain Chinese tracts, on the whole
it is an independent development of Japanese
thought. At the same time it is not be con-
founded with ancestor worship, with which
many Japanese and most European authorities
do identify it. Although in its modern observ-
ance ther is, perhaps, too much of the ancestor
worship element, Shintoism bespeaks the adora-
tion of a god, not the mere worship of man. Much myth and a confusion of the godheads
has crept into the Shinto Pantheon, the latter
embracing many degrees of nature gods. In
the older Shintoism th evarious types occupied a prominent position, but one among them, the
Phallic symbolism, has long disappeared.

In the earliest stage of the religion, Shinto-
ism possessed its Government Busea, and the
Mikado eas at once the high priest as well as
the leader of the nation. Even nowadays the japanese Sovereign occasionally officiates at
some of the Shinto rites, but more frequently
he deputes his sacerdotal fucntions to some
on else. Again, Shintoism can hardly be said
to possess a code of morals, but if ethics are
conspicuous by their abscence the doctrine of
cleanliness holds a prominent position. Fre-
quent bathing and the constant change of
raiment were imposed upon its believers, while certain acts of a sexual character were accom-
panied by religious penalties, although adul
tery did not, and does not, constitute a Shinto
offence.

At the present day most of the former ela-
borate ritual of Shinto is neglected or shorn
of its ancient magnificence, the decline dating
back to the appearance of Chinese philosophy, as well as Buddhism, in the Island Kingdom.
Under the inlfuence of Buddhism a more
humane note crept into Shintoism, while the
patronage of Buddhism by certain Mikados
caused the earlier faith to lose some of its
standing, as well as its holding upon the
people. To-day there is no doubt that Shinto-
ism has fallen from its heigh estate. Without a code of morals, or an efficient ecclesiastical
organization, wiht little aid from the arts of
painting, sculpture, and even architecture, and with but a scanty literature, it is doomed to
ultimate extinction among a people familiar
with the religious and moral ideas of India,
china, and Europe.

"Shinto: The Ancient Religion of Japan." By
W. G. Ashton, (London Constable and Co) 1s. net,

div.head: Death by suffocation.
div.p:
4 A native residing at Boulac died from the
effect of swallowing a lemon, which lodged in
his throat, causing suffocation.

div.head: Cotton Worm.
div.p:
Owing to the advanced state ot the cotton
crop, 26 provisional employes on cotton worm
duty have been dismissed, their services being
no longer necessary.

div.head: Arrival of Specie.
div.p:
The Minister of Finance has received from
England by S.S. "City of Oxford" 242 cases
of specie in nickel and bronze.

div.head: Bubonlo Plague.
div.p:
During the last twenty four hours one fresh
case, two'deaths, and one recovery have been
reported from Alexandria. There are now 5
cases under treatment.

div.head: Murder or Suloide.
div.p:
The. Hellenic Consulate has given instruc-
tions to the Public Safety Department to have
an enquiry opened in connection with the
suspected suicide of a cashier in the Bank of
Athens, Aristide Joannides, who is supposed
to have thrown himself into the Nile.

div.head: Kank Embezzelment.
div.p:
A few days,ago Samuel Levy, cashier in
the National Bank, Cairo, stole £22,000 and
disappeared. The French Consulate was im-
mediately informed, and police investigation
discovered Levy in his house suffering from
a bullet wound, caused while cleaning a re-
volver.

div.head: Quarantine Department.
div.p:
The Ottoman Delegate has informed the
Ministry of the Interior that by the decision of
the Superior Council of the Sanitary Depart-
ment at Constantinople the quarantine against
arrivals from Alexandria will be increased to
three days observation in the lazaret and dis
infection of vessels.

div.head: Crime,at Tourah prieon.
div.p:
One of the prisoners at Tourah prison, em-
ployed as a tailor, is reported to have killed
three of his fellow prisoners with a pair of
scissors. It is stated that the murderer had
committed an offence against the rules which
had been witnessed by his victims, and he co-
mitted the triple crime in order to suppress
all evidence. The murderer is undergoing a
sentence of 20 years.

div.head: Frenchman on the "Chico Anglais."
div.p:
The great French caricaturist, "Sem," is
at present in London studying types for his
album of London celebrities. "Sem's" real
name is M. Goursat. Interviewed the other-day
he expressed his appreciation of the "Chic
Anglais” -the English aristocrat -as the finest
in the world. The young Frenchman, he said,
copied him both in his clothes and his de-
meanour. As for the English ladies, he thought
they were perfect, or would be if they did
not make the mistake of dressing in the French
fashion. He does not like the smart set, but
he misses the cafes and the dejeuner out of
doors.

div.head: Stolen Rubens Recovered.
div.p:
The "Petit Parisien" states that the missing
Rubens picture "Bacchanale d'enfants," which
was stolen from the residence of the Comte
Edouard d'Asshe, in the Avenue Louise, at
Brussels, last week, has been discovered by
Paris dectectives in a house in the Rue Bau-
din, and that a Brussels waiter, who was
found lodging in a house, has been arrested,
charged with the theft. The picture, which
is valued at £4,000, was carefully packed up,
but without its frame, and it is believed that
it was the intention of the arrested man to
take it to America.

div.head: The Mex Baths.
div.p:
The Mex baths continue to be well patronis-
ed by the Alexandrian public, and though
the time is coming when they must disappear
we trust the Municipality will extend their
lease to the utmost limit. The site is all that
could be desired, the air of Mex is noted for
its salubrity, and the baths are so safe that the
danger to swimmers is minimised, while every
precaution has been taken to render assistance
in cases of unanticipated accidents. The
establishment is most comfortably installed,
and the bather will find at these baths
everything he may require. Under the
management of Mr. Prinea a. most com-
fortable restaurant and well-served bar has
been attached to the baths, and every meal of
the day can be taken there with the assurance
of good service and an excellent cuisine.

div.head: Mustapha Carrison Theatre.
div.p:
On Wednesday and Thursday next enter-
tainments will be given at the Regimental
Theatre(gymnasium building) of the Royal
Dublin Fusiliers at Mustapha Pasha by Mr.Bert
Flatt, the well-known American musical come-
dian who will be assisted by Miss Violet
Esdaile, Miss Annie Letine, Miss Lilian Lewis,
Sergeant Byrne, Messrs. G. Winch, Stroud,
Panton, Mooney, and Evans. The programme
will consist of serio-comic songs, sentimental
songs, dances, a comic sketch, instrumental
solos and. the latest American picture songs
illustrated in colours. The doors will open at
8 p.m. and the concert will commence at
8.30pm. each evening. The prices of admit-
tance are P.T. 10, PT. 5,and P.T. 3. For the
benefit of those attending the concert and
going from Alexandria by tram we might
mention that descent should be made at Sidi-
Gaber, the gymnasium being the second large
building on the left. Tickets should be booked
at once as nearly all the seats for Wednesday
evening have been already reserved.

div.head: POSTPONEMENT OF DEPARTURE.

p.hi: (Gazette's Special Service.)

div.p:
LONDON, Monday.
The Khedive has postponed his departure
from Egypt until Wednesday in order to be
present at the Sultan's birthday celebrations.

div.head:
PORTS AND LIGHTS
SCANDALS,
div.p: WRIT SERVED ON GOVERNMENT.

Mr. Albert Simha, late director of stores in
the Ports and Lighthouses Administration has,
we learn, served a writ on the Egyptian Go-
vernment for defamation of character and
wrongful dismissal.

Much comment is being made upon the
constitution of the Council of Discipline, which
has recently dismissed so many employes of
the Ports and Lights, and we understand that
its legality will be contested in the forth-
coming action on the grounds that a Court of
Enquiry cannot legally resolve itself into a
Council of Discipline at its own discretion,
which seems to have been the case with the
present court.

div.head:
NEW ANGLICAN ARCHDEACON
FOR EGYPT.
APPOINTMENT OF CANON WARD.
div.p:
The Right Reverend Bishop Blyth, D.D.,
Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem, and the East,
has appointed the Rev. Canon Algernon
Ward, M.A., Archdeacon of the Church of,
England in Egypt in place of the Right
Reverend Bishop Morley, D.D., who has just
resigned.

Archdeacon Ward was formerly curate of
St. Michael's, Coventry, senior curate of St.
Angustine's, Edgbaston, for nine years, and for
some time tutor and sub-Warden_of Queen's
College, Birmingham.

In 1902 he was appointed by Archbishop
Temple, Chaplain of St. Mark's, Alexandria,
and in 1904 was promoted to an Hon Canonry
of St. George's Cathedral Church, Jerusalem.
He is the editor of the calendar for the
Bishopric, and the anthor of several theological
books.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAY
LOCOMOTIVES.
div.p:
Mr. F. H. Trevethick, general manager of
the Egyptian State Railwtys has adopted a
new method of heating the feed water for loco-
motives working between Cairo and Alexandria
which is described in a recent issue of the
"Revue Industrielle." The water is heated by
the exhaust steam in combination with the
waste heat of the smoke box gases. The feed-
water is forced into the boiler by a horizontal
motor pump placed on the left-hand side of
the fire-box, and using steam at full boiler
pressure. The water passes from the pump
through the first heater, which is formed of a
cylinder set vertically between the frames be-
low the feed pump. It is 36 ins. high and con-
tains ninety steel tubes 7-16 ins. in diameter,
about which the exhaust steam is made to
circulate. The steam condensed by the cold
feed-water is collected in the bottom of the
cylinder and is removed by a pipe and cock.
The feed-water is taken from this first heat
er and sent on through a pipe 2 1/2 ins, in
diameter to second and third heaters, which
are set horizontally outside the cylinders in
such a way as to receive a part of the exhaust
steam on its way to the stack. The condensing
surface, which is the same in the three, is
formed of forty-two tubes 7-16 ins. in diameter
and 5-ft. 6 ins. long, set in a cylindrical box.
The second heater, which on the right-hand
side, is divided by a partition in such a way
that the water traverses it twice in going
through; in the third heater there is no such
partition. The water passes from the third
heater into a fourth heater, formed of an an-
nular chamber placed in the smoke-box, and
containing 265 water tubes of 1 in. inside
diameter and 18 ins. long, arranged in three
concentric rings, which finally deliver to the
boiler on its centre line directly back of the
smoke-box.

div.head: THE COTTON SEASON.
div.p:
During the week ending Friday, 64,125
cantars of cotton arrived at Alexandria from
the interior, of which 2,484 bales were export-
ed to England, 1,767 to the continent and 125
to America. 179,787 cantars are now in stock
at Minet-el-Bassal.

Messrs. Collinge Brothers report from Liver-
pool under date of 14th inst-- We have had
an exceptionally excited market this week,
brought about by the Report of the Ginners
Census which shewed 191,000 bales ginned to
the linst., and by the Burean's "condition" of
72.7 (against 75 last month). Both reports
were considerably above expectations and the
result has been heavy liquidation and general
selling, "futures" being 38 to 47 points lower
than last Friday(6 inst.) Present Prospects as
shewn by the Bureau's Report and based-on
the record acreage planted, seem to point to a
crop of about 13 millions provided we have a
late frost.

div.head: LETTER TO PREMIER
div.p:
Telagraphing from Paris on the 15th inst.
the "Standard" correspondent says :- Most
leading papers reproduced yesterday a letter
published in the "Figaro," addressed nominally
to Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman by Mustafa
Kamel, but in reality intended probably as an
irritant trial of French opinion. If this is the
case, Kamel has signally failed, as hardly &
single comment was made yesterday, and the
"Figaro" itself, which gave the hospitality of
its columns to the original publication, today
finally disposes of any hopes which Egyptian
agitators may haye entertained of finding
support in France. Upto 1904 the Egyptian
Nationalists certainly based their expectations
on. French assistance, but the "Figato" says
that since the agreement with England they
ought to, know that when France has, given
her word she keeps it. So far as British occu-
pation goes or British policy in Egypt, France
is dumb. But there is a point on which the
"Figaro" feels at liberty to say a few words, and
it says them as follows:-

"Very sincerely do we, believe that the Eng-
lish make one mistake in attributing the
aspirations of the Nationalists to foreign inspi-
ration, and we think that it would be to the
interests of Britain to give more weight to
convictions which may hamper her momen-
tarily, but whose genuineness seems to us
beyond doubt. In the work accomplished. in
Egypt a distinction must be drawn between
the substance and the form. The result attained
is, beyond criticism, but the way of attaining it
has often been had. The eminent organizer,
Cromer, was wanting in political tact, and a
contempt for the people he governed interfered
with his foresight. The Denshawi affair, was an
incontestable instance of this.

"His colleagues, Sir Vincent Corbett, who
has since retired, and Messrs. Dunlop and
Boyle, who are still in office, have always
aggravated, by their characters, the painful
side, to the Egyptians of the duties they had
to perform. And the French, too - witness the
case of Lambert-have not always escaped
their vexations. Here we have a method of a
system and persons that it would be a mistake
to consider out of reach of attack. England
would be better served by moderation and
kindness. Correct attitude and abstention from
extremes on the Egyptian side, liberality and
good grace on the British--these are what are
wanted."

The reception of Kamel's letter by the Paris
Press should act as a decided cooler on the
ardour of Egyption agitators, particularly on
those of the stamp of the writer, who though
he writes his appeals with French ink on
French paper, may giye up all hope of impart-
ing any other French colour to his complaints.

div.head: A MEMORABLE DAY.
div.p:
The Pasha recalls that the day, September
14, is a day memorable in the history of Egypt.
It is the centenary of the evacuation of Egypt
by British troops and at the same time the
twenty-fifth anniversary of their entry into
Cairo. The day has a double interest in that
it reminds Egyptians of the glory of their
fathers who defended their country and forced
England to renounce the conquest of Egypt
during the space of a century, while at the
same time it gives Egyptians cause to remem-
ber the official declarations which accompanied
the present occupation and the engagements
definitely entered into by England.

"Few Englishmen," adds the National leader,
"give thought to-day to the promises made by
that Government of Queen Victoria, or to the
many speeches made by her Ministers, who
declared that the continued occupation of
of Egypt by England would be shameful for
the Bristish Throne and the British Empire.
But we Egyptians have not forgotten them,
and, in spite of those who affirm that politics
are but lying and cheating, we cannot believe
that a great nation will continue to soil its
history by a nameless spoliation. If the lessons
of history are insufficient to prove to British
Imperialists that Egypt can belong only to the
Egyptians, the awakening of the Egyptian
naition should show them that the future of
Egypt lies with liberty and independence."

The Pasha declares that misfortunes only
serve to strengthen the patriotism of the Egyp-
tians. Denshawi did more for the development
of Nationalism than the greatest efforts of
Egyptian patriots have ever done.

"The problem before you, sir," he adds, "and
before the British nation, is whether England
desires to make a friend or an enemy of Egypt.
If England considered evacuation possible in
1890, and had even fixed the date for it in the
Drommond-Wolff Convention, how can she
maintain that it is impossible, to-day? What
Liberal can serionsly contend that the hour
for the evacuation has not yet struck, when
Gladstone recognised, in the letters which he
wrote me in 1896, that the hour of evacuation
had struck several years ago? You have your-
self declared in one of your speeches that even
a good Government can never replace self-
government, I say that where a people is consci-
ous of its rights nothing will make it forget its
independence, and a foreign Government, even
though it be a model of benignity (douceur) is
always hated and execrated. A nation like
ours which through the centuries has acoumt-
lated forces of patience and energy does not
know despair, and will not be hindered by. any
obstacle in the work of reconquering its inde-
pendence. It remains for a Liberal England to
decide whether that independence shall be
realised with or without its consent."
The "Times" Paris correspondent announces the letter as follows:-

An Egyptian Nationalist agitator whose
articles have more than once found their way
into the columns of the Paris Press seizes the
opportunity offered by the two-fold anniversary
yesterday of the evacuation of Egypt by the
England in 1807 and of their entry into Cairo
in 1882, to address an open letter to Sir Henry
Campbell-Bannerman, which is published in
the "Figaro". It is not of a nature to excite
more attention that the previous preoductions
of the same gentleman. The cause he represents
publicity which certain newspapers courteously
extend to his communications.

div.head: CAIRO AND ALEXANDRIA.
div.p:
This match was resumed on Saturday at
2 p.m. H. B. Carver and Prosser bowling to
Shuttleworth and Pte. Rice. Rice was out
almost directly and Shuttleworth run out
through a misunderstanding for a veru useful
22. The last wicket gave some trouble and
the innings closed for 159, thereby a-
head of Aexandria.

The Alexandria batting order was altered
in second innings the brothers Carver
going in first against the bowling of Graves.
and Wright. Had Cairo taken all their catches
the home team might have been dismissed
for a vry small score, for H. B. Carver who
played the highest innings of the match was
dropped twice early in his innings. H. P.
Carver was soon bowled in trying to hit
Graves, and Prosser fell to a fine catch at
point. W. E. Peel followed and by hard
hitting knocked up 26 which included 5 fours,
during his innings. Marsden, Mainprice and
and McLean leaving. Seven wickets were
down for 140. Barnard was bowled for 173
and the innings declared for 8 wickets, Hay
being not out 36.

The declaration left Cairo with 144 runs to make in an hour and 35 minutes. Though Preston was out in the first over Wright and Shuttleworth played good forcing cricket till the former fell to a good catch in the long field for a most useful 27 Sergt. Smith helped Shuttleworth to add a few, and Sherringham then came in and played good cricket, being very severe on the home change bowlers who were very inaccurate in the length. With 110 up he fell at last to a shortish ball from Prosser who had resumed bowling and with Shuttleworth, who also played extremely well out to a good catoh by Hay, Alexandra seemed to have a chance of at least staying off defeat. With Major Hos- kins bowled at 124 a victory for the homesters seemed just possible, but Private Rice coming in was not in the least affected by the situation and hit the first, ball he received off his middle stump to long leg for 4. Three more boundar- ies and several singles bronght the score up to a tie and at this point Boyes, who showed equal sang froid, hit a two and Cairo were winners by four wickets 3 minutes from time. The Cairo eleven was well captained and though at times uncertain in the field contained some excellent workers. The home team was good in the field but very weak in bowling.

div.p:
The Earl of Cromer has postponed for de-
parture for Egypt, and will remain at Dunbar,
East Lothian, till about the end of this month.

Sir Eldon gorst has been staying at Glen-
borrodale Castle, Ardnamurchan. Sir Eldon,
who is a keen deer stalker, has had very
excellent sport on the hills, several fine heads
having fallen to his rifle.

Scandar pasha Fahmy and constantin Bey
Cotta arrived from Europe this morning by
the S.S. "Hohenzollern."

The marriage took place this morning at ten
o'clock of Mr. Francis Hubert Manley, of
Alexandria and of Spofforth Hall, Yorkshire
to Miss Gladys, only child of Sir Alfred
Moloney K.C.M.G., J.P., late governor of
Trinidad, now of Cefutilla Court, Usk.
Monmouthshire, and the late Constance Lady
Moloney. After the ceremony Mr. and Mrs.
Manley left for a motor-car trip round
Scotland.

Capts. C.J.B. Daubeny and C.J. Ryan, 2nd
Battalion Essex Regiment have been specifically
selected for service with the Egyptian Army,
Second Lieutenant D.V.F. Anderson, Royal
Dublin Fusiliers, from attached 2nd Battalion,
has been appointed to the 1st Battalion, now in
Egypt.

The Rev. F.J.B. Brown, of curate of High Wy-
combe, has been appoited to the staff of the
Archbishop's Mission to the Assyrian Christ-
ians in Kurdistan.

Professor L. F. Vernon Harcourt, M.I.C.E,
the eminent engineer, who died last week, was
last year appointed British member of the Suez
Canal Works Consultative Commission.

The marriage will take place on Thursday next
at Stuttgart of Mr. G. Runkewitz, of Ramleh,
Alexandria, and Luxor, to Miss Emma Junger,
daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Junger of Stadt
garten, Stuttgart.

The marriage took place on the 14th Sept.,
at the Greek Church, Agia, Sofia, of Constan
tine, Xydis, of Alexandria, Egypt, to Helen
Sevastopulo, daughter of D.S. Sevastopulo, of
69, Ladbroke-grove, London.

The arrivals from Constantinople yesterday
by the S.S. "Ismailieh" included abdel Khalek
Bey Sarawat, Sadik Bey Abaza, Ahmed Bey
Assad, Hussein Pasha Shahin, Emin Pasha,
Shoukri Pasha, Mohamed Ali Bey, Ali Bey
Dlaver, and the family of Ghazi Mukhtar
Pasha.

div.head: ESBRKIEH GARDENS THEATRE
CYRANO DE BERGERAC.
div.p: (From Our Own Correspondent)

Could heroic enterprise go further ? In the
Gardens Theatre too! But its fullfilment
amply earned the success. Really the per
formance was most admirable and the house
which was packed--not a stall or a box to be
had when the curtain rose--showed its appre-
ciation repeatedly and heartily. M. Silvestre
was a worthy Cyrano, his voice, rich, vibrant,
full of colour, ranging from tenderness to rage,
from the sardonic to the self pleased, his vary-
ing facial expression, his swift and graceful
gesture all heightened his admirable inter
pretation. Perhaps at moments he insisted
overmuch on the, Coquelin roar and drawl :
but the balcony scene, the Cadets de Gascogne,
and above all the journey to the moon were
splendid. Mile Theulee we know for an ex-
cellent and versatile actress: her only fault
seemed to be a tendency to self-possession
hardly in accordance with the vaporous. nature
of a 'precieuse,' but in the camp scene she
excelled. De Guiche (M. Berthoud) Was most
dignified in his rage, irony, or vengeance
Rageneau (M. Henris) was an admirable pastry
cook-poet: Christian (M. Goidsen) was quite,
good. The whole troupe played with a vigour
and enthusiasm that carried through the
minor parts and indeed the whole play with a
swing. The Gascons were one and all worthy
of their regiment: and one could well over
look the small. deficiencies in staging and
costume and inevitable in so small a theatre.
A friend remarked to me by the way on
the apparent exaggeration of the acting,
but surely M. Rostand's play is more or
less a delightful gascounade throughout : what
else could it be? It's, hero, a poet, poor, unpro-
tected save by his own fierce and reckless sword
the best gaurdian of his reputation, his verses
and his nose--its heroine a blue stocking who
drives through the enemy's lines right to the
post of danger,--its least characters roystering
swaggering blades who hesitated to prefer
fighting to eating alone--drunk on powder as
when the bravo and the soldier reigned supreme
in the word of men, and the ultra Roman-
ticiste in the world of women. And we had all
this in the dead sense continue, and its success be as
sure sample as it was last night.

div.head:
The
Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p:
Will be open during Winter.
REDUCED PRICES. 30979-22-9-908

div.head: EGYPTIACA.
THE TOMB OF QUEEN TEIE.
div.p:
Professor A. H. Sayce writes to the "Times"
as follows:--

I have just recieved a letter from Mr.
Theodore M. Davis, the fortunate discoverer of
the tomb of Queen Teie at Thebes, relative of the communication of your "Occasional Cor
respondent," in which the writer announces
that Dr. Elliott Smith's examination of the
bones from the tomb proves them to have been
those, not of the Queen, but of a young man.
Your Correspondent, however has gone wrong
in one important particular; the inscription
on the mummy-case does not state theat it
belonged to the King Akh-en-Aten, but that
it had been given by the King to his
mother Teie. If Dr. Elliot Smith's con-
clusions are corroberated, all his dis
covery woyld prove would be that the mum-
my of the Queen had been torn to pieces like
that of the King; and that, subsequently when
an attempt was made to put the tomb in order,
the first mummy that came to hand was thrust
into the Queen's jewelry wrappings, and coffin.
It was not the first time that the Egyptian
resorted to similar measures, and it would
explain the otherwise puzzling absence of funer
al furniture in the tomb.

But Mr. Davis brings forward evidence
which seems to throw doubt on the results of
Dr. Elliotts Smith's examination. He tells me
that immediatley after the opening of the tomb
he had the mummy examined by Dr. Pollock
of Luxor, "and a prominent American Obste-
trician." In the presence of the doctor and
surgeon, Mr. Ayrton, and one or two other
persons, the mummy was opened and the bones
exposed. In fact, the mummy had absorbed so
much moisture that it could not be unwrap-
ped, but it yielded to the touch and disin-
tegrated to such an extent that there was no difficulty in exposing the bones from
end to end. The pelvis was admitted to be the
criterion of the sex. Both doctor and surgeon
insantly agreed that it was the pelvis of a
woman. The surgeon made a most thorough
examination, and expained to us that it was a
woman's pelvis, and what the difference is
between the pelvis of a man and woman. He
practically stated that the 'greater breadth of
the pelvic arch gives one of the most easily
appreciable points of contrast between the male
and female pelvis; the pelvic arch in the female
forms an angle of from 90 deg. to 100 deg., while
in the male it averages from 70 deg. to 75deg."

div.head: THE "OLIVEMOOR"
div.p:
The salvage steamer "Berger Wilhelm"
came into harbour on Saturday night with a
heavy cargo of cases of whiskey and these were
discharged and landed yesterday morning. The
"Olivemoor" is now free of general cargo and
only coal remains in her holds to be jettisoned.
A second salvage steamer is on her way out
to assist the "Berger Wilhelm" and should
arrive diring the course of the day. A bad sea
was running on Saturday night, there being a
very heavy swell, but since then the conditions
have greatly improved and are to-day most
favourable. The salvage steamer, which return
ed to the "Olivemoor" this morning, is now
standing some 500 metres away.

div.head: THE SCARLET MYSTERIES.
div.p:
We are glad to learn that towards the
end of the present year or at the commence-
ment of January next we are to have a
short visit from the world-wide famed and
deservedly popular Scarlet Mysteries, and
we have no hesitation if prophesying for
such a renowned company a complete success
--even in Cairo and Alexandatia, whose popula-
tions frequently disdainfully refuse to recog-
nise historionic talent. The fame, however, of
the Scarlet Mr. E's. is such as none can
ignore, and no matter where they per-
form they can be sure of bumper houses
and enthusiastic appreciation. We shall give
Mr. Edward Branscombe's company a most
hearty welcome, in which the English com-
munities of Alexandria and Cairo will
unanimously join us, and all will be well
repaid for their support by assisting at
entertainments which Egypt has never before
witnessed and which, we can say from expe-
rience, will be of exceptional excellence

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p:
The String Band of Kings Own Scottish
Borders will play the following programme of
Music, (by kind permission of Colonel D.A.
Macfarlane D.S.O. and Officers) in the Eshbekieh
Gardens to morrow from 9 to 11 p.m.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p:
The "Caledonia" will lie at berth No. 30
on arrival to-morrow and not at the bouys as
stated in our issue of Saturday.

The Moss Liner "Seti" arrived on Saturday
evening last, from Liverpool via Gibraltar,
Algiers and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p:
Le Casino restant ouvert cet hiver, la direc-
tion a decide de continuer les spectacles cine-
matographiques du jeudi et du dimanche. Il
sera aussi emis des abonnements de'hiver pour
l'entree au Casino, a valour du 15 Octobre au
15 Mal, a raison de P.T. 200 l'abonnement de
famille et P.T. 100 l'abonnement simple.
